content: Diffusion 25 Steps (50NFE) APT 1 Step (1NFE) Diffusion 25 Steps (50NFE) APT 1 Step (1NFE)
caption: Table 1: One-step image generation compared to their corresponding original diffusion models in 25 steps.
description: This table compares the performance of one-step image generation models against their original diffusion model counterparts trained for 25 steps.  It shows the percentage difference in user preference scores across three criteria: visual fidelity (how realistic the image looks), structural integrity (how well the objects are formed), and text alignment (how well the generated image matches the text prompt). A positive percentage indicates that the one-step method is preferred, while a negative percentage means the 25-step method is preferred.

caption: Table 2: Comparison to the state-of-the-art one-step image generation. Both absolute and relative preference scores (adjusted for base model performance) are presented. The methods are sorted by average preference.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed Adversarial Post-Training (APT) method against state-of-the-art one-step image generation models.  It presents both absolute and relative preference scores based on user studies.  The relative scores are adjusted to account for differences in the quality of the underlying 25-step diffusion models used as baselines. This adjustment provides a fairer comparison across models with varying baseline performance levels. The table is sorted to show models in order of decreasing average preference score, allowing for easy comparison of the effectiveness of different one-step generation techniques.

caption: Table 3: Comparison of other base diffusion models with our base model for image generation. All models are evaluated using 25 steps. Since our model is designed to handle both video and image generation, its image generation performance is slightly inferior to FLUX and SD3.5.
description: Table 3 presents a quantitative comparison of image generation performance across different diffusion models, all evaluated using 25 steps.  The models compared include various versions of SDXL and FLUX.  The study highlights that while the authors' model is designed for both image and video generation, its image-only generation performance is slightly lower than that of models exclusively trained for image generation, specifically FLUX and SD3.5. This underscores the trade-off of a multi-modal versus a single-modal model design.

caption: Table 4: Comparison of one-step (and two-step) video generation with the original 25-step diffusion models.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of video generation results.  It contrasts the quality of videos generated using the proposed Adversarial Post-Training (APT) method, both in one-step and two-step generation, against videos generated by the original 25-step diffusion model. The comparison is based on three key metrics: visual fidelity, structural integrity, and text alignment, reflecting how well the generated video matches the prompt in terms of visual quality, structural correctness, and alignment to text descriptions.  Positive percentages indicate improvement over the baseline 25-step model, while negative percentages show degradation.

caption: Table 5: Quantitative metrics on COCO5K across different models and methods. We find the metrics inaccurately capture the actual performance of the model. Discussion are provided in Appendix A.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of various image generation models, including different one-step methods and their corresponding 25-step diffusion model baselines, using three metrics on the COCO-5K dataset: Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Patch Fréchet Inception Distance (PFID), and CLIP score.  FID assesses overall image similarity to real images, PFID evaluates fine-grained detail preservation, and CLIP score measures the alignment between image and text descriptions. The results highlight a discrepancy between the quantitative metrics and perceived visual quality, indicating limitations in relying solely on these metrics for evaluating image generation models. A more detailed analysis and discussion of these discrepancies can be found in Appendix A.

caption: Table 6: Quantitative metrics on COCO10K. The metrics also inaccurately capture the actual performance of the model. Discussion are provided in Appendix A.
description: Table 6 presents a quantitative evaluation of various image generation models using the COCO-10K dataset.  Metrics such as Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Patch Fréchet Inception Distance (PFID), and CLIP score were calculated to assess the generated images' quality.  The table compares the performance of different one-step and 25-step diffusion models. Importantly, the caption notes that these quantitative metrics do not fully reflect the actual perceived quality of the generated images, and a more in-depth discussion of this discrepancy can be found in Appendix A.

caption: Table 7: Inference speed under different numbers of H100 GPUs for one-step two-second 1280×\times×720 24fps video generation.
description: This table presents the inference time required to generate a two-second, 1280x720, 24 frames-per-second (fps) video using the Adversarial Post-Training (APT) model.  It shows how the processing time changes based on the number of NVIDIA H100 GPUs used for parallel processing. The table breaks down the computation time for each component of the video generation pipeline (text encoder, diffusion transformer (DiT), and Variational Autoencoder (VAE)) and shows the total time required when using different numbers of GPUs. This allows for an assessment of the model's scalability and efficiency with varying computational resources.
